resources.string: We can use the pH Scale to measure how basic (alkaline) or acidic things are.

Have you ever tasted a lemon and puckered up? Lemons have that puckery taste because they\'re acidic, just like vinegar and some other foods. Scientists use the pH scale to describe whether something is acidic or basic. Basic is the opposite of acidic.
The pH scale goes from 0 to 14: 0 is the most acidic and 14 is the most basic, or alkaline. Plain water is right in the middle of the scale with a pH of 7. This is called a neutral pH

If you want to try things with high acidic pH, first take a cup of milk, milke has a pH between 6 and 7,so it\'s just a little more acidic than water. If you drank some coffee, you\'d be down to a pH of 5. Also if you had some orange juice, you\'d be looking at a pH around 3, and lemon juice has a pH of 2

Now let\'s take a look at things that are more basic or alkaline than water. The first step up from tap water is…sea water! the pH would be about 8. Moving on up the pH scale, baking soda is next at a pH around 9.5. Moving on up the pH scale, we start moving into dangerous cleaning chemicals, like bleach. Bleach has a pH of around 13.5.
